prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In their 2021 article published in Physica A, L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. illustrate the social layers of a proposed multi-layer network in Figure 2. The nodes in the network represent people, with consistent identities across all layers. Weighted connections between nodes indicate social contact that could potentially lead to infection, with edge weights representing probabilities within the range of 0 to 1. The first layer of the network captures home interactions and consists of various groups of different sizes, each fully connected internally. These groups are isolated from external connections, effectively representing individual families as disconnected components. The researchers based the creation of these groups on the distribution of Argentine family sizes in 2009, encompassing family sizes ranging from 1 to 14 members and considering the probability of family sizes up to 10. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . In any country, a significant portion of the population must work or engage in economic activities that involve interaction with others. This makes work a crucial factor in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model this activity, we suggest a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's total population. Creating accurate connection rules to mirror the diverse job market and companies is challenging. We propose a common scenario where random groups of sizes between 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, similar to the "home" layer. An illustration of this layer with 100 nodes is depicted in Fig. 2(b). Transmission of the virus within a group depends on edge weights, detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in cities but dense and can facilitate the spread of diseases due to constant movement. Our third layer represents these transports for individuals without personal vehicles, with usage rates varying based on city size. On average, 50% of the population is considered for the "transports" layer, grouped randomly with sizes between 10 to 40, and fully connected internally. This strategy aims to capture the diverse travel patterns observed in cities.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (Physica A 564, 2021), a multi-layer network model was proposed to analyze social interactions and possible infection transmission. This model consists of different layers representing various social settings, with nodes representing individuals. The connections between nodes are weighted to represent the probability of infection transmission. The first layer of the network represents home interactions, with groups of varying sizes fully connected internally. These groups are based on the Argentine family size distribution for 2010, with each family ensured to have at least one adult member. Another layer in the network represents work interactions, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59 years, representing 60% of the population. This layer reflects the importance of work activities in social relations, especially in epidemic scenarios. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . Although all nodes within a group are connected, the spread of the virus is directly influenced by the weights of the edges, as detailed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation plays a crucial role in most cities, as they are often crowded environments and can contribute significantly to the spread of an epidemic due to constant movement. The third layer of our model represents these public transportation systems, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of people using public transport varies depending on the city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging about 1.2 hours of usage per day. Considering an average participation rate of 50% between both scenarios, individuals are randomly assigned to groups of sizes ranging from 10 to 40, with fully connected nodes within each group. This approach is based on data showing that Argentinians spend an average of 1 hour and 20 minutes daily on public transportation [1].

author: enrique
pre_context: Scabini et al. (2021) explored the impact of various strategies on the course of an epidemic, analyzing changes in case numbers, fatalities, and hospital bed occupancy. In their simulation, the infection initially starts at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spreads over 300 days in daily iterations. The study assumes an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 23 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities still ongoing represent essential services that were unable to be halted, despite taking strict precautionary measures and disregarding the quarantine. In this context, we examine the impact of the β parameter on the overall shape of the epidemic. Fig. 4(a) displays the results for 4 different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a quicker spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity among recovered individuals. 

To validate the model, we compare its output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18. Fig. 4(b) illustrates that using β = 0.3 provides a better fit to the actual data, reflecting the current situation in which individuals are wearing masks and taking extra precautions against infection. The model shows a significant similarity to the real data within its standard deviation. Discrepancies in the number of diagnosed cases in recent days may be attributed to increased testing in Brazil or a decline in isolation levels below 50% in the past month. The model assumes a fixed isolation level based on initial observations after government mandates, but actual data indicates fluctuations in these levels. As a result, the simulated number of cases and deaths may be higher than reported in this study. 

Regarding daily death rates, the average from the model exceeds official numbers, which could be due to higher underdetection rates and limited testing. Further analysis is needed to fully comprehend the implications.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined the impact of various actions on the progression of an epidemic, including the increase and decrease of cases, deaths, and hospital occupancy. The simulation began with a social network consisting of all its layers and original infection probabilities. The infection started at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread daily for up to 300 days.

The study considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the outset, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represented a form of natural social distancing, with reduced direct contacts and precautions against transmission. The researchers empirically determined that this initial β value better matched the situation of the Argentinean pandemic.

After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was implemented to mimic the measures adopted by most Argentinean states on March 24, including Buenos Aires. This quarantine involved removing certain layers of activities, reducing contacts in transportation and workplaces to 30% of their initial value (β = 0.09). Some essential services and activities that continued with higher precautions were exceptions to the quarantine.

The study investigated how the β parameter influenced the overall shape of the epidemic. Results from the simulation for four different β values over 300 days indicated that higher infection rates led to faster disease spread and more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ended quicker due to natural immunization of recovered individuals.

Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentinean epidemic (up to May 19) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a noteworthy overall similarity within its standard deviation. The significant difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be attributed to the increase in testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country (which has been below 50% for most days over the past month). We assumed a fixed isolation level similar to what was observed in the early days after the government decrees in Argentina. However, data from the same source indicates that these levels are constantly changing. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the remaining simulation may be higher than what is reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). In terms of daily death toll, the average number from our models is higher than the official figures, which is expected due to potential underdetection rates and limited testing. To illustrate this further, we analyzed the number of deaths in Argentina between January 1 and April 30, comparing data from 2019 and 2020. A clear increasing trend is observed after February 26, the day of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll could be significantly higher than reported.

Looking ahead, we contemplate four potential actions that could be taken after 90 days (by May 26) following the initial phase of the epidemic: a) Maintain current isolation levels; b) Lift isolation measures and return to normal activities (initial network layers and weights); c) Resume only work-related activities, restoring the initial layer probabilities; or d) Intensify isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, and colleagues published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers analyzed the total number of infected and recovered cases along with the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three different scenarios after 90 days (May 26). These scenarios included: (a) maintaining current isolation measures with restrictions on schools, religious gatherings, work, and transportation, (b) ending isolation and returning to normal activities, and (c) increasing isolation by halting work and public transportation.

The study found that testing is limited due to various factors such as the low number of available tests or the rapid spread of the virus that exceeds testing capabilities. As a result, the researchers assumed that only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed in their analysis.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days since the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were put in place, including the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity (resulting in a decrease of the β term). Various options were considered after 90 days from the first case: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, lifting isolation completely and returning to 100% activity, or only returning work activities. Studies revealed that maintaining current isolation levels would lead to prolonged spread, nearing the estimated peak around June 5 with approximately 11,000 new cases and 1900 new deaths daily. By the end of the year, an estimated 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths may occur. Hospitals could reach maximum capacity by June 11, but the addition of new ICU beds and efficient patient management could mitigate the situation. However, this relies on the assumption of social isolation levels above 50%, as observed at the start of the Peruvian quarantine. Currently, social isolation levels in Peru remain consistently low at 12%.

Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the impact of different scenarios on the spread of infection and hospital bed utilization after 90 days was examined. Three possibilities were considered: maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing limitations were noted due to a lack of resources or the rapid spread of the virus. It was assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus. Optimistic assumptions were made regarding infected individuals isolating themselves at home if they were aware of their symptoms, while severe cases were expected to be hospitalized and removed from the network.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and

To account for gradual noncompliance with universal masking, Equation (10) is proposed, incorporating parameters βnc and k2 to model the slight increase in infection rates as individuals begin to engage in noncompliance due to pandemic fatigue and complacency. This gradual increase in noncompliance is expected to have a different effect on infection rates compared to the abrupt reduction seen with enforcement of compulsory mask wearing. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. 6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the 3 scenarios outlined, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values through simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where full compliance and no time-limited immunity is considered, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different days: (a) when the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all. 
Analysis of Figure 3 reveals that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and a longer time to reach it. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right and the value decreases. The infected number rises until reaching a global peak, followed by a decline as predicted by compartmental models.

Delay Dynamics of Compulsory Mask Wearing By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined above, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) on the day of the first COVID-19 case in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) no enforcement at all. From Figure 3, it is evident that earlier implementation of mask wearing not only decreases the Maximum Infected Value but also prolongs the time taken to reach this peak value. This is shown by a rightward shift in the peak of the Infected compartment curve and a lower maximum value. The infected numbers rise until they reach a global peak and then decline, as expected from compartmental models. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value. With a (b) 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is around 10.479%, peaking on day 195. [25]. In order to assess the impact of delaying public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers caused by the B117 variant, we conducted a simulation using a hypothetical scenario. Comparing our study to similar research by Eikenberry et al. [3], we found that delaying mask enforcement had little immediate impact on hospitalizations or deaths, but could lead to a 'point of no return'. Their study focused on New York and Washington states, while ours was specific to the context of Singapore. Our study is valuable as it provides a more accurate representation of smaller city states with different epidemiological parameters. text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint of an agent-based epidemic model called REINA for COVID-19 was posted on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this non-peer-reviewed work and has granted medRxiv permission to display it under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The model aims to identify effective policies for managing the COVID-19 pandemic, as different countries have implemented varied approaches to combat the virus.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, with interventions such as physical isolation, testing, tracing, and controlling the entry of cases. The open-source code allows for various strategies to be implemented, such as hospital capacity through mobility restrictions and aggressive testing and tracing of positive patients and their contacts. The model starts at February 18, 2020, and diverges from the actual situation on April 6, 2020. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow the spread of the epidemic in the Helsinki University Hospital region, with a focus on suppression strategy. Please note that this preprint presents new research that has not been peer-reviewed and should not guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The article uploaded to medRxiv on April 17, 2020, discusses a coronavirus agent model. It includes a diagram showcasing different states of the agents, transitions between states, infection pathways, and targeted or broad population subgroups under varying degrees of social isolation. The model considers an "incubating" state for individuals who may spread the virus before showing symptoms. The healthcare system's properties such as hospital and intensive care bed capacity, testing modes, number of tests conducted daily, and testing queue length are also detailed. This preprint is available under a CC-BY 4.0 International license.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model monitors all contacts made by infected agents, allowing for analysis of various testing and tracing protocols. text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Estimating the Transmission Risk of the 2019-nCoV and Its Implications for Public Health Interventions, Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu discuss the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV and its impact on public health interventions. The authors are affiliated with various institutions in China and Canada.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions in Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to significantly increasing quarantine measures. It is crucial to evaluate the effectiveness of the costly measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV, as well as determining their duration. Under strict measures, the outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks, with a lower peak value. Implementing travel restrictions can lead to a 91.14% decrease in infections in Beijing within seven days. Coronaviruses, which have caused major outbreaks in the past, are known for causing mild to severe respiratory infections. Three notable outbreaks include SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012, and MERS in 2015.

post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23). Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk. The impact of travel restrictions implemented by Hubei on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing is nearly equivalent to increasing quarantine by a baseline value of 100 thousand. It is crucial to evaluate how the costly and resource-intensive measures implemented by Chinese authorities can help prevent and control 2019-nCoV infection, and determine their duration. By imposing travel restrictions (preventing imported exposed individuals from entering Beijing), the number of infected individuals in Beijing is expected to decrease by 91.14% within seven days compared to a scenario with no travel restrictions. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The intensity and transmission range of respiratory infections vary geographically due to differences in vulnerable populations and risk factors that affect the spread of pathogens. This has significant implications for the unequal capacity of healthcare systems and disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately impacted the Northeastern United States, with more cases and deaths reported. The reasons for these regional disparities are not fully understood at this time.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our objective is to forecast the spatial and temporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in conjunction with the availability of healthcare resources in Ohio. 

To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that simulates the transmission dynamics of COVID-19, incorporating county-level geographic connectivity information. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, classifies the population into susceptible individuals (S), confirmed infections (I), hospitalized and ICU-admitted patients (H), recovered individuals (R), and deceased individuals (D). 

Building upon previous research that identified local air hubs and main roads as critical geospatial factors associated with differential COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020; Cuadros et al., 2020), we divided the SIHRD COVID-19 model into four distinct spatial risk groups based on a defined connectivity index for each county. These risk groups were categorized as follows: Group 1 includes counties with airports seeing over 50,000 passengers annually, Group 2 comprises counties neighboring those with airports, Group 3 consists of counties traversed by main highways, and Group 4 includes counties not adjacent to airports or intersected by main highways. 

The dynamics of disease transmission and infection progression within each group were modeled using seven epidemiological compartments for the SIHRD COVID-19 model. Susceptible individuals in each spatial group faced varying hazard rates for exposure to infection, which were contingent upon the group and time to account for the fluctuating risk of exposure and the impact of public health interventions.

Counties with local air hubs in Group 1 saw a faster and more widespread epidemic, while rural and less connected counties in Group 4 experienced a slower and less severe spread of the disease. The COVID-19 infection rate was nearly three times higher in Group 1, with an average of 274 cases per 100,000 people, compared to 85 cases per 100,000 people in Group 4. Hospitalizations related to COVID-19 were also twice as high in counties with local air hubs, with an average of 48 hospitalizations per 100,000 people compared to 23 in less connected counties. The non-spatial adjusted model overestimated infection rates in Group 4 and underestimated them in Group 1. Additionally, there were significant disparities in critical healthcare capacity among counties, with Group 1 having the highest capacity of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people compared to Group 4.

The COVID-19 pandemic consists of multiple sub-epidemics varying in intensity, even within the same country. Outbreaks have occurred in different locations across the U.S. at different times, with each state implementing various control measures at different stages, resulting in significant variations in disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate model performance using data from diverse locations. Despite these limitations, this study presents one of the first spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, aiming to simulate spatial disparities in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, cumulative hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and beyond.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: States and national governments in the US implemented widely varying responses to the pandemic despite facing similar circumstances. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to aid in decision-making by allowing for predictions tailored to specific environments. While these models may not accurately reflect reality due to uncertainties in input parameters and potential for exponential growth, they can still assist in selecting effective interventions for COVID-19. A case study on the use of simulation models at Cornell University showcases their utility in guiding intervention design. Additionally, a modeling framework is proposed for use in other universities to support decision-making processes.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work informed the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and played a crucial role in designing an asymptomatic screening program that remains a key part of Cornell's strategy. As per our modeling recommendations, all students were welcomed back to campus for residential instruction during the 2020–2021 school year under an asymptomatic screening program, with 75% of students returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing based on our modeling for testing frequencies. The program opted for anterior nares (AN) sampling over nasopharyngeal (NP) sampling for comfort, as our modeling indicated that the benefits in test compliance outweighed potential sensitivity loss. Cornell enabled asymptomatic surveillance through a significant effort to facilitate large-scale sample collection and establish a new COVID-19 testing lab in collaboration with a local health care provider. Following suggestions from our simulation modeling, the strategy was updated for the spring 2021 semester to increase testing frequency for varsity athletes and Greek-life organization members due to their higher levels of social contact. Similar adjustments were made for fall 2021 to account for the Delta variant, changes in social distancing protocols, and vaccination effects. Throughout the 2020–2021 academic year, fewer than 1,044 infections were recorded among students and staff, which was lower than many schools with comparable student populations that offered only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying the input parameters that are critical for controlling epidemics successfully.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, we conducted a Bayesian analysis to investigate the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate. To do this, we adjusted our model using data from the previous academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant. We increased transmission rates by a factor of 2.5 to reflect the presence of the Delta variant and incorporated parameters for vaccine effectiveness on transmission and susceptibility to infection. We assumed 95% of the Cornell student population was vaccinated, a number that later rose with the vaccination of incoming international students. Various changes had occurred from previous semesters, such as the removal of social distancing restrictions and adjustments in contact tracing protocols. This led to uncertainty in transmission rates and contact tracing outcomes. By sampling parameters and running simulations, we were able to update our prior assumptions to more accurate estimations. Fig. 6A displays the distribution of these parameters, showing that while individual uncertainties exist, the overall product of these parameters is more focused.Fall 2021 modeling. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Individuals with confirmed 2019-nCoV cases are identified and diagnosed at varying rates over time, reflecting the availability of resources in the area. The rate of diagnosis, represented by dI(t), is determined by a formula that accounts for an initial rate (dI0), the fastest rate (dIf) reached at an exponential rate as time progresses, and a constant (r2). By adapting a previously derived formula to include time-dependent coefficients, we define ðtÞ as the effective daily reproduction ratio. This ratio measures the daily reproduction number, or the number of new infections caused by a single infected individual during their infectious period. Data on confirmed cases, deaths, recoveries, and new cases is gathered from the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China and updated daily.

Parameter estimation process Under the gradually enhanced control strategies since January 23rd, 2020, the parameter values with substantial changes include the contact rate, the diagnose rate and the quarantined rate q. Therefore, we fixed the parameter values except these three as the estimated values in our previous study (Tang et al., 2020). The initial contact rate c0 is assumed to be the average contact rate between January 10th, 2020 and January 22nd, 2020, hence c0 ¼ 14:781. With the same assumption, we set
post_context:
.The starting conditions can be determined by solving our previous model (Tang et al., 2020) from January 10th, 2020 to January 23rd, 2020 in order to estimate the parameter values q, cb, r1, dIf, r2. The Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method is used to fit the model to the data, employing an adaptive Metropolis-Hastings (M-H) algorithm for the MCMC process. The algorithm runs for 70,000 iterations with a burn-in period of the first 50,000 iterations, and Geweke convergence diagnostic method is utilized to evaluate convergence. Results are shown in Table 1.

Since Hubei was placed under lockdown on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions have been imposed nationwide and advancements in coronavirus detection technologies have improved case confirmation speed. Due to the changing circumstances, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer sufficient for predicting the epidemic trend. Using updated data, the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) is parameterized to re-estimate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov. By calculating the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) shown in Fig. 1(a), we can determine the effective daily reproduction ratio, R(t), as seen in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that under strict prevention measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio (Rd) has been less than 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. The effective daily reproduction ratio decreased from January 23rd, 2020 to January 25th, 2020, due to a combination of measures such as the Hubei lockdown, contact tracing, and quarantine protocols.

pre_context: During the period of self-isolation for all individuals, including those who are susceptible, we consider the rate of diagnosis to be a function of time. This function is inversely related to the time of diagnosis, with a specific formula that accounts for different diagnostic rates over time. This rate is influenced by the resources available in the area affected. By adjusting the formula used in a previous study to include time-dependent coefficients instead of constant rates, we defined a new parameter to measure the daily reproduction number, which indicates the number of new infections caused by a single infected individual each day. The data used in our analysis was obtained from the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China and includes the cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed cases of 2019-nCov. The data information includes the cumulative confirmed cases, the cumulative number of deaths, newly confirmed cases and the cumulative number of cured cases, which are reported daily by the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China. Parameter estimation process Under the gradually enhanced control strategies since January 23rd, 2020, the parameter values with substantial changes include the contact rate, the diagnose rate and the quarantined rate q. Therefore, we fixed the parameter values except these three as the estimated values in our previous study (Tang et al., 2020). Since the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were imposed across the country and case confirmation speed improved with new detection technologies. To evaluate the epidemic trend in the near future, the basic reproduction number needed to be updated. The model (Tang et al., 2020) was parameterized with updated data to re-estimate the 2019-nCov transmission risk. By calculating the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a), the effective daily reproduction ratio was determined as shown in Fig. 1(b). It was observed that under strict prevention and control measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has been below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. The reduction in the effective daily reproduction ratio from January 23rd to January 25th, 2020 was attributed to the combination of measures, including the lockdown of Hubei and reduced contact.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Controlling and containing the spread of the coronavirus outbreak can be highly effective by focusing on reducing the percentage of transmission. Researchers like Yu have calculated a basic reproduction number of 3.5, indicating that a quarantine rate of over 90% of the infectious population would be necessary to effectively control the outbreak. Another study by Kucharski and team utilized a stochastic SEIR model with a time-step of 6 hours and a transmission rate following a geometric Brownian motion. By estimating the time-varying reproduction number using the sequential Monte-Carlo approach and incorporating multiple datasets, the researchers were able to provide real-time estimates despite data reliability challenges. The model considered transmission as a fluctuating random process, similar to previous research by Imai et al., and assessed the risk of causing a large outbreak based on negative binomial offspring distribution. Overall, the median reproduction number ranged from 1.6 to 2.9 before travel restrictions were put in place.The study by Wu and collaborators (Wu et al., 2020), based on nowcasting and forecasting approach, estimated a basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) with 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) being infected in Wuhan as of January 25th, 2020. The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). Authors computed a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to
post_context: (95% CI 1.99e2.18) on January 22nd, 2020.According to estimates, the pandemic outbreak is projected to decrease significantly within 77 days (95% CI 75e80) from the start. A study by Majumder and Mandl (2020) using the IDEA model estimated a reproduction number between 2.0e3.1, while Riou and Althaus (2020) found a reproduction number of 2.2. Liu et al. (2020) estimated a reproduction number range of 2.90 to 2.92 using statistical techniques. Zhang and Wang (2020) found the most recent common ancestor of the virus to be on December 17th, 2019, with a reproduction number oscillating between 1.1 and 1.6. These variations in findings may be attributed to differences in methodology, models used, datasets, and estimation periods. The reproduction number was observed to fluctuate over time, reflecting the dynamics of the outbreak and case reporting.

Another study by Shen et al. (2020) predicted 8,042 infections (95% CI 4,199 to 11,884) and 898 deaths (95% CI 368 to 1,429) with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26 to 12.78%), and found a basic reproduction number of 4.71 (95% CI 4.50 to 4.92), decreasing to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99 to 2.18) by January 22nd, 2020. Based on these calculations, it is anticipated that the pandemic outbreak will significantly decrease within 77 days (95% CI 75 to 80) from its onset. Additionally, the researchers observed that reducing the time from illness or symptom onset to isolation by one day could lead to a 72% to 84% decrease in the peak population size, as well as a 68% to 80% decrease in the total number of infected cases and deaths.The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). post_context: .Variations in findings may stem from methodological differences, such as assumptions, parameters, models (stochastic/deterministic, compartmental/IDEA), datasets, and estimation periods. Comparing updated versions of studies revealed fluctuation in the reproduction number, reflecting the evolving transmission dynamics of the coronavirus outbreak and case reporting patterns. In particular, the reproduction number typically rose with increasing reported cases. Results were notably influenced by the estimation period and available data. It is important to note that the reliability of model frameworks and analysis techniques vary.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Disease modelling research has drawn on previous studies of the SARS outbreak to understand the current situation with the 2019 n-Cov outbreak. Similarities have been noted, such as high basic reproduction numbers in hospitals and lower numbers in the general community. However, the scale of the outbreak in Wuhan, with its large population and widespread travel before containment measures, sets it apart. The situation is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and across China. Effective control measures are crucial and depend on available resources for frontline workers and patients. Factors such as speed of diagnosis and hospitalization play a key role in determining the peak value and time of the outbreak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trajectory of an epidemic and determining its peak time requires real-time data and knowledge about resources available for public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We would like to thank the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, the Fields Institute, and the Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory for their support. No competing interests were declared. References include studies on the novel Wuhan coronavirus and strategies for controlling outbreaks like SARS.

text: large-eddy simulations of the ascent of a buoyant meltwater plume after its escape from beneath an Antarctic ice shelf.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Could you please provide a different version of this text so that it conveys the same meaning but is paraphrased?JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the significant impact of localized variability in stratification on the vertical distribution of meltwater near Pine Island Glacier, contributing to observed interannual variability. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, a dynamic parameterization of meltwater settling depth is essential for accurately simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this discussion, we explore potential developments following this research and identify remaining challenges. Keywords: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change.

Introduction:
One of the notable shortcomings of global coupled climate models in CMIP5 has been their inability to accurately replicate observed Southern Ocean climate trends, such as surface cooling, freshening, and sea ice expansion. The increase in Antarctic meltwater anomaly may have influenced these trends. Climate models often overlook the freshwater flux from Antarctic ice sheet mass loss, which has significantly increased in recent decades. Incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help reconcile the differences between observations and simulations, potentially explaining the observed trends. Additionally, the incorporation of Antarctic glacial meltwater could have a significant impact.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context:
Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.Results from various simulated scenarios show that neglecting social distancing and hygiene measures can have catastrophic consequences on the human population. The model demonstrates that isolating cases and quarantining contacts can effectively slow the spread of the novel coronavirus. Keywords: SEIR model, COVID-19 dynamics, Social distancing, Mathematical model, Basic reproduction number, Runge–Kutta method 

Introduction: Coronaviruses are a diverse group of viruses known to cause illnesses ranging from the common cold to severe diseases like severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The emergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) as the cause of a pneumonia outbreak in Wuhan, China in late 2019 led to a global health crisis. In February 2020, the World Health Organization declared the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), a global pandemic. The objective of this study was to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic under different intervention scenarios and provide insights into the most effective interventions to mitigate the epidemic risk. Numerous researchers have explored mathematical modeling of the novel coronavirus, utilizing models developed for Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) to estimate transmission rates during different periods affected by intensive interventions.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The pathogen present in the environment is referred to as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) holds true. Research has revealed that COVID-19 can spread in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic individuals (IA(t)) and symptomatic individuals (IS(t)) infected with the virus can transmit it to susceptible individuals (S(t) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment. Since the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for some time, those in close proximity to these areas are at risk of exposure, especially in the early stages of the outbreak before proper hygiene measures are put in place. As the disease spreads, susceptible individuals move to the exposed population (E(t) due to an incubation period in the host. The model illustrates the interaction between the human population and the pathogens in the environment. The parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model are listed in Table 1. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations, as seen in Fig. 1.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Mwalili et al. (2020) conducted a study focusing on the complex interactions between humans and the environment in relation to the spread of SARS-CoV-2. A mathematical model was created to examine the transmission dynamics of the virus within two populations: humans as hosts and the pathogens. The model divided the human population into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. It was found that the virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, were shown to spread the virus to susceptible persons they come in close contact with. Additionally, the virus can spread to the environment through coughing or sneezing if proper precautions are not taken by infected individuals.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. post_context: respectively.Amid the outbreak, health experts and governments are recommending social distancing to limit contact with infectious individuals. In our model, we propose that new infections occur through interactions with infectious individuals (α2S(IA+IS ) in the form 1+α2(IA+IS )), considering the proportions of susceptibility to infection from the environment and from infected individuals (α1 and α2). Equilibrium points and the basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving relevant equations. The disease-free equilibrium point occurs when there are no infectious or exposed individuals, resulting in the calculation of the basic reproduction number. This number indicates the potential spread of infection in a fully susceptible population. The next generation matrix approach is used to calculate the basic reproduction number. Derivatives of F and V at the disease-free equilibrium point provide additional insight into the model.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The study findings presented in Table 1 indicate that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 through various contacts such as households, workplaces, schools, foodstuffs, and during commute. This results in a surge of the virus in environments like workplace, school, foodstuffs, and public transport, as shown in Fig. 2b, ultimately leading to a rise in confirmed cases of coronavirus within 10 to 35 days, as depicted in Fig. 2a. In this model, the constants α1 and α2 are considered to be reciprocals of the frequency with which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. The model in Fig. 2 demonstrates that when α1 = 0.05, indicating a high risk of contracting the virus from a contaminated environment compared to an infected individual, there is an increase in the number of exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, indicating higher chances of getting infected by an individual compared to a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly, with susceptibility vanishing by the 23rd day for α2 = 0.05 due to rapid spread of infection, as seen in Fig. 2d-f for the first 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention through serological shielding to prevent transmission of the virus is outlined in Table 1. This policy summarizes the process of shielding individuals based on their susceptibility, infectiousness, and recovery status. It classifies individuals based on whether they test positive or negative for the virus and antibodies.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While questions still linger about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategically identifying and deploying recovered individuals presents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive strategies to end the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, ultimately resulting in fewer than 25% of the population becoming infected compared to the expected 90% without protective measures. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for its application to COVID-19, capturing the conservative benefits of shielding, though more detailed models could offer further insights. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the pandemic, focusing on susceptible, exposed, and infectious individuals, as well as hospital care requirements for severe cases. Age-specific risks for hospitalization and severe cases are based on previous research, shaping potential outcomes for the United Kingdom and the United States. Our comprehensive model incorporating shield immunity expands upon traditional SIR models by considering social distancing measures.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated the effectiveness of 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as alternative substitution mechanisms for interactions. In a flexible shielding mechanism, the interaction rates of recovered individuals are increased by a factor of (1 + α) compared to others while maintaining the total contact rate. On the other hand, in a fixed shielding mechanism, the interaction rates of recovered individuals are increased by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate while total contact rate remains the same. Our findings, as shown in Extended Data Fig. 1, suggest that shielding is effective in both scenarios and may even be more effective. For instance, in the case of fixed shielding with α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented.The results presented in Figure 3 compare various shielding interventions to a baseline outbreak. Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to reduce the burden of an epidemic across multiple metrics, decreasing the total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline case compared to 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding (α = 2) and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding (α = 20). It is important to note that our simulation considers only the effects of shielding, while additional measures such as social distancing and shelter-in-place orders can further decrease interaction rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on the identification of potential shields and their substitutability, denoted as αRshields. Population-scale impacts of shielding are influenced by various factors including demographic distributions, the fraction of asymptomatic transmission, and the duration of immunity. It is suggested that populations with a larger proportion of older individuals may benefit more from shielding interventions.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context:
We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our predictions show that without any interventions, over 14 million lives would have been lost by May 17, 2020. Starting interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths worldwide. Among the interventions studied, mass gathering restrictions and school closings had the highest average reductions in infection rates at 29.6% and 17.3%, respectively. The most effective policy was the stay-at-home order, which led to an average reduction in infection rates by 74.4% from baseline in countries that implemented it. Additionally, we showcase DELPHI's capability to forecast future COVID-19 incidence under different government policies, with an example of how Janssen Pharmaceuticals used this analysis to select trial locations for their vaccine candidate. The e-companion with supplemental material can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases, partial identifiability.

Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic, as of June 1st, 2022, stands as one of the most fatal in recent history, with over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths. In response to this crisis, we developed DELPHI in late March 2020, an epidemiological model that extends the classical SEIR model to consider additional outcomes like deaths, address underdetection of infections, and assess the impact of varying government interventions. DELPHI has consistently been featured among the top models used by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for forecasting.

post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. discussed the importance of R0 in measuring the potential spread of infections in a susceptible population. R0 represents the average number of new infections generated by one infected patient at the beginning of an epidemic. Controlling the effective reproduction rate, Rt, is crucial in keeping the epidemic under control, with values below 1 indicating successful mitigation efforts. Policies such as stay-at-home orders have shown to be effective in mitigating the spread of the virus, although at a significant economic and social cost. Timing of these policies is crucial in minimizing the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling alternative responses, such as implementing mitigation measures earlier, can significantly reduce the impact of an epidemic. For example, starting interventions one week earlier could have prevented a significant percentage of cases and deaths globally, especially in Western European countries. Delphi predicts that a large number of deaths could have been avoided with earlier mitigation efforts. Failure to mitigate the epidemic could have resulted in a much higher death toll by a certain date.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
In this research article, the authors model the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The coronavirus disease has spread quickly in Japan and to over 30 countries in the past two months. The authors are affiliated with the CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, the Japan National Center for Bioinformation, the School of Future Technology, and the CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics. The research was received on February 29, 2020, revised on March 4, 2020, and accepted on March 4, 2020.

COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Nanjing, Jiangsu (excluding Nanjing), Japan (excluding Jiangsu) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context:
, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19.

Our model estimates the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Nanjing at 0.0643, which is lower than Jiangsu excluding Nanjing (0.1914) and Japan excluding Jiangsu (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was factored into new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Nanjing, which decreased to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Nanjing and Jiangsu by late March, in Japan excluding Jiangsu by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities by early March. In Japan, a total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected, with 49,510 in Nanjing, 17,679 in Jiangsu (excluding Nanjing), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions. It is important to note that these estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and carry some uncertainty. Our conclusion is that strict quarantine and control measures should continue until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Fukuoka, and until late March in Jiangsu. Our model can also be applied to predict the epidemic trend in other countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Our SUQC model was developed to address the unique characteristics of COVID-19, including high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures.

pre_context: RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India was conducted by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen from various research institutes in India. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and more than 30 countries over the past two months. This disease has unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Introduction: COVID-19 has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,

The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some uncertainty. text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and economy. This study, conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models to understand the spread of the virus.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for guiding policymakers and health authorities in their strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020. Since then, Brazil has been severely impacted, with over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths as of June 26th, 2020. The coronavirus crisis has not only affected public health but also various other aspects of life including politics, education, economy, social issues, environment, and climate. To combat the outbreak, strict social distancing measures have been recommended based on numerous studies. Many countries have implemented these measures with varying degrees of success. Due to the complexities of societies, accurately predicting the future outcome is challenging.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Probabilistic models already account for uncertainties in data by assigning a probability distribution to data points at each time point, with the mean and variance determined by the assumed model. Lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modelers. Understanding how confirmed cases align with model predictions is crucial in explaining prediction variations. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who tested positive for COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all infected individuals, including those without symptoms and individuals not captured by testing. This discrepancy between confirmed cases and total infected population is likened to an iceberg, with the visible tip representing case data and the submerged portion symbolizing the undetected infected individuals, often referred to as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why might this pose a challenge for modelers? In model calibration, estimating key parameters like the transmission rate b requires accounting for the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), in the model prediction by using the case-infection ratio r to predict confirmed case data accurately. By varying the ratio r, different values for the transmission rate b can be determined through model fitting, which then influences the basic reproduction number R0, the scale of the epidemic, and the peak time. Due to the wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary greatly, resulting in a range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, means that different combinations of r and b can provide equally good fits to the data but lead to divergent epidemic predictions. The way nonidentifiability is handled in model calibration has a significant impact on the reliability of model predictions. Traditional nonlinear least squares methods are ineffective in addressing nonidentifiability because they use basic optimization algorithms that may find multiple global minima for the objective function.

author: chunwei
pre_context: When evaluating models, support for model i decreases if Di is below 7 and the model can be omitted if Di is greater than 10. Model selection rules may vary when considering a large number of models or when they are not nested, and readers are encouraged to refer to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020) for further information on model selection.3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Chengdu, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Chengdu, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment (E) is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. This is biologically realistic for COVID-19 infection, as there is an incubation period of up to 14 days during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period (time from infection to infectiousness) and the incubation period (time from infection to symptom onset). For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, while for COVID-19, evidence suggests that individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the susceptible, exposed, and infected compartments can be ignored during the modeling period. Data calibration for both models focuses on newly confirmed cases, with the death term in the recovered compartment having no impact on model fitting. The differential equations for each model are provided, and calibration from the data is discussed for reliability.
