post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.Here we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of clinical symptoms like fever and coughing for COVID-19. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms start, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. For COVID-19, evidence suggests individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the exact length of the latent period is unknown. post_context: . The SEIR model includes a latent compartment E for individuals infected but not yet infectious, reflecting the realistic incubation period of COVID-19 up to 14 days. This differs from the latent period (time from infection to infectious) and incubation period (time from infection to symptoms) of the virus. While SARS becomes infectious after symptoms, COVID-19 can be spread before symptoms appear. The SEIR model is biologically accurate, but requires parameters like latent period and initial population. Both models assume negligible deaths in compartments S, E, and I during predictions. The systems of differential equations for each model are provided, with data calibration based on newly confirmed cases.

the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 20, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.After the mayor of Nanjing announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population N = S + I + R in Nanjing on January 20 to be around 6 million. The same uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters were used as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models, as shown in Tables 1 and 2. We utilized the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to generate posterior distributions for all estimated parameters, resulting in the best-fit values and 95% credible intervals detailed in Tables 1 and 2.

Upon comparing the SIR and SEIR models in Section 3.3, we calculated their corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc to be 174 and 186, respectively. The significant difference of 12 between them indicates that using the SEIR model would result in a considerable loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, we will proceed with further investigation using the SIR model.

Our calibration results of the SIR model in Section 3.3 revealed a linkage between the transmission rate b and diagnosis rate r. This linkage is depicted in Figure 2, showcasing the connection between the two parameters.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, including medical, surveillance, and administrative records, as well as published literature, can be used to calibrate models. This can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens that occur in real-time, such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One approach to address this challenge is to utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence intervals. Our fitting procedure, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Chongqing consist of prediction intervals generated by sampling the posterior distribution randomly. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference utilized newly confirmed cases in Chongqing reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the city's lockdown and travel restrictions. These projections depict our estimation of the potential epidemic in Chongqing if additional control measures weren't implemented post February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R_c. For (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Chongqing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our analysis, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases is estimated to reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Chongqing would likely continue until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for individuals with different severity levels of symptoms. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may either recover or succumb to the illness, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. Transmission of the virus occurs with a probability of β whenever a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual. A value of β = 0.016 in a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. The exact values depend on factors like population size and age structure. The default value of β = 0.016 used in Covasim was calibrated based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were chosen with a weighting of 10:2:2:1 in order to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, about 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can adjust the value of β. We allow for variations in individual infectiousness over time based on viral load, which peaks around symptom onset and then decreases gradually. By default, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage lasting for 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter, followed by a longer low stage. Each agent's viral load is determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45. This approach is consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for each agent. Fig 2 shows the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values.

Viral load is highest around symptom onset, declining thereafter. Model assumes two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is crucial for the user to adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. If the model includes a realistic network structure incorporating households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for community contacts, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types, aiming to have a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a population without different network layers. When considering the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors in a typical transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events without interventions is roughly 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can also be influenced by interventions like physical distancing. Furthermore, in addition to allowing for variations in disease severity and duration in each disease state, the model accounts for individual differences in infectiousness by using individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, as seen in the estimated proportions for Seattle. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced in individuals without symptoms. While we assume it is not by default, there is a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling application or context. It is important to note that some studies have reported much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals.
